Text: these include the anti-immigration swiss peoples party, which received the largest share of the vote in the countrys parliamentary elections in october 2015, in what was described as the best performance by a party in at least a century.57 they also include the progress party in norway, which won in 2013 with 16.3 percent,58 the national alliance in latvia, which won in 2014 with 16.6 percent,59 the finns party in finland who rose to power with 17.7 percent in 2015,60 and the victory of the belgian new flemish alliance in 2014 with 20.3 percent.61 beyond elected governments, internationally occurring sympathy toward an expanding field of right-wing nationalism is evidenced by growing public support for far-right political entities. such entities include the greek golden dawn party, which came third in greeces september 2015 election, and whose spokesman ilias kasidiaris bears a swastika tattoo and denies the official history of the holocaust.62 under the infamous leadership of geert wilders, the burgeoning party for freedom in the netherlands spearheaded a call for the country to leave the european union, while wilders asserted: islam is not a religion, its an ideology, the ideology of a retarded culture.63 also far-right, and remarked upon almost as frequently as trump in western media, is marine le pens far-right national front party, which was defeated in a high-profile race in france on 23 april and 7 may 2017.64 although le pen and other political figures have historically denounced imperialists and communicated anti-american sentiments, they have recently expressed solidarity with the trump administration in the u.s. at a january 2017 gathering of far-right leaders in koblenz, attended by wilders, le pen, frauke petry of the alternative for germany (afd), and matteo salvini of italys northern league, wilders announced their collectivized support for trumps policy platform with the twitter hashtag #wewillmakeourcountriesgreatagain.65 united patriots front social media within an expanding field of right-wing politics, over facebook, twitter, and youtube, united patriots front members have expressed a far-right habitus by evoking the rhetoric and ideologies of european and u.s. politicians.
attributes.response: [YES, 'Frauke Petry of the Alternative for Germany (AfD)']

Text: both sites also formerly served as a semi-official campaigning arm of former australian senator fraser anning in the run-up to the country’s may 2019 federal election, after anning’s delivery of his ‘final solution’ maiden speech in the australian parliament (delivered on 14 august 2018),2 his employment of neo-nazi activists from the lads society, and statements anning made referring to ‘muslim immigration’ as causative in the massacre of 51 muslim worshippers at two mosques in christchurch, new zealand, on 15 march 2019 by brenton tarrant, an australian neo-fascist (baker, 2019). to explore xyz and tu’s engagements with political philosophical traditions that were far-right at their inception, or that have since become integrated into far-right-wing politicking, this paper outlines a critical discourse and content analysis of articles published on their websites.

Text: australian civil liberties union vice-president jonathan graham regularly refers readers to the protocols in his column in the far right publication, the strategy, claiming it is “not a forgery but a blueprint which can be seen being put into action....”²¹ toben’s deputy until november 2000 was the berlin-born david brockschmidt, who had an unusual background for a holocaust denier. his parents were declared righteous among the nations for helping supply trucks to oscar schindler during the war, and he spent eleven years working for the british army in the rhine region as a civilian, and two years in israel from 1977–1979 before settling in australia.²² brockschmidt describes “the schemes of the international jews” engaged in a “world-wide conspiracy for the overthrow of civilisation and for the reconstruction of society on the basis of arrested development, of envious malevolence, and impossible equality.”²³ this is based on his belief in “the cunning and crafty behaviour of powerful jewish groups in the financial world, in the world media, in global culture, in world politics and in practically all aspects of life,”²⁴ while simultaneously referring to the “anti-gentile babylonian talmud” as “the root of evil.”²⁵ in tasmania, the adelaide institute’s olga scully has made the distribution of the protocols a regular part of the adelaide institute’s work, together with cartoons portraying ugly hooked-nose jews sitting on piles of money and tricking the world into their conspiracy.²⁶ when distribution of the protocols led to a hearing 20 rodney gouttman, “the protocols and the printer,” journal of australian jewish historical societies 11 (1990): 155–59.
attributes.response: YES

Text: founded by wanda marsh, john oliver and catherine brennan in early 2015, reclaim australia marketed itself as a group of parents worried about the “spread of islam” across australia (cullen and peters, 2015). the group’s ideological manifesto (posted on their now removed website) included topics such as: compulsory singing of the national anthem every week in every school, revoking citizenship for those who do not pledge allegiance to australia, stopping the perceived spread of sharia law, and putting a halt to the perceived islamisation5 of australia (ali and khattab, 2017).
attributes.response: YES, 'founded by wanda marsh, john oliver and catherine brennan in early 2015'

Text: apart from browne, founding members included quentin spedding, an employee of ezra norton's daily mirror, for whom browne also worked, john hawkins, a sydney solicitor, and ken gates, a waterside worker.56 all these men had been involved in the battle veterans' association that waged a campaign within the returned soldiers, sailors and airmen imperial league of australia (rsl) to ban communists. the origins of this association lay in 1946 when browne was involved in a stunt throwing a red flag at the then president of the rsl.57 later hawkins, in particular, became prominent in the australian party.58 upon his release from goulburn gaol in september 1955, browne contributed a series of articles about his experiences as an inmate to the daily mirror.59 these were browne at his best, justifiably railing against his incarceration and damning his enemies, in particular prime minister menzies and the leader of the opposition, dr evatt.

Text: founded by wanda marsh, john oliver and catherine brennan in early 2015, reclaim australia marketed itself as a group of parents worried about the “spread of islam” across australia (cullen and peters, 2015). the group’s ideological manifesto (posted on their now removed website) included topics such as: compulsory singing of the national anthem every week in every school, revoking citizenship for those who do not pledge allegiance to australia, stopping the perceived spread of sharia law, and putting a halt to the perceived islamisation5 of australia (ali and khattab, 2017).

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nation’s title, which was akin to confederate action party’s slogans ‘we are one nation’ and ‘one flag one nation’.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, ‘all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing’, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nation’s expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisis—the cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading ‘new world order’—much of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tony’s wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archer’s criticism of hanson that led to archer’s expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australia’s leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: [YES, 'Tony Pitt gave secret recordings to David Ettridge']

Text: greason (1997) described them as developing since the second world war in three broad waves: the explicitly nazi nationalist socialist party of australia (nspa) in the 1960s; the less symbolically laden (that is, no swastikas) national front of australia and the australian national alliance during the 1970s and early 1980s; and national action (na) from the early 1980s onwards. a return to explicit nazi ideology and paraphernalia was evident in the national action breakaway group, the australian nationalist movement (australian nationalist movement), formed in 1984 because its leader believed that national action was insufficiently explicit in its anti-semitism and neo-naziism.

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nation’s title, which was akin to confederate action party’s slogans ‘we are one nation’ and ‘one flag one nation’.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, ‘all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing’, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nation’s expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisis—the cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading ‘new world order’—much of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tony’s wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archer’s criticism of hanson that led to archer’s expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australia’s leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: YES, 'David Ettridge was given secret recordings by Tony Pitt's wife, leading to Peter Archer's expulsion.'

Text: however, events soon showed that australians against further immigration had not developed a consistent strategy which bound its leadership. sue hammond, who served australians against further immigration briefly as new south wales chairperson in mid-1995, was in confederate action party when she first advocated a new extreme right political and electoral front.117other leaders like terry cooksley and peter krumins had argued that too,118 but the new members who demanded electoral action and the new south wales leadership around edwin woodger who were also keen on subordinating ideological development and cadre development to electoral contest, considered australians against further immigration alone could alter the political climate on multiculturalism and immigration by a major electoral campaign.

Text: eric wenberg, a member of the  australian national socialist party and then the national socialist party of australia, travelled to the united states in 1967 to make links with rockwell and his american nazi party.15 after rockwell was assassinated in august 1967 by a former member of his organization, wenberg disrupted the trial of the killer by trying to punch him and was deported from the united states with 235 a certain amount of notoriety.16 when assessing the risk that wenberg posed after his deportation from the us, asio suggested: while wenberg may seek some advantage from his recent press publicity on his return to australia, there is no evidence to suggest that the national socialist party of australia consists of other than a very small number of individuals of questionable mental stability who profess nazi beliefs. they are essentially at variance with each other, and their activities have not extended beyond the sporadic distribution of nazi propaganda emanating originally from the united states and the united kingdom.17 cawthorn and molnar launched the australian national socialist journal in the summer of 1968, which demonstrated its links to the rockwell and jordan groups overseas.
attributes.response: YES, Edward Cawthorn and the Australian National Socialist Journal are explicitly connected as they launched the journal together in 1968.

Text: the groups also appeared to share a belief in the politicized nature of the courts, demonstrated after hanson was fined and the party deregistered by the australian electoral commission. as the adelaide institute said: ‘the courts have quite obviously, and most probably unlawfully, taken the law into their own hands and set out to destroy an individual in the hopes of squashing a growing political movement.’68 the adelaide institute was joined by australia’s other main holocaust-denial organization, the australian civil liberties union (aclu), headed by john bennett, which published praiseworthy statements in hanson’s defence.69 as töben agreed with hanson about the courts, bennett appeared to do likewise in relation to the elitism of the media, arguing that there was a campaign against hanson by commentators, ‘many of whom doubtless see themselves as part of some sort of cultural and intellectual elite’.70 although there is no record of hanson espousing holocaust denial there were holocaust-deniers in the party.
attributes.response: [YES, 'The Adelaide Institute was joined by Australia's other main holocaust-denial organization, the Australian Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), headed by John Bennett, which published praiseworthy statements in Hanson's defence.']

Text: the true nature of the league of rights – one nation relationship was articulated by butler’s successor, david thompson, who told the league of rights supporters they should ‘resent’ claims that one nation is a the league of rights front, which he dismissed as an attempt to undermine support for hanson.6 in the organization’s most explicit statement on one nation he wrote: ‘while we have made every effort to distribute pauline hanson’s addresses as widely as possible, and offered every encouragement to others to support her in the raising of the issues with which she has become associated, the league of rights has had no contact with pauline hanson whatever’ (italic and underlined in original).7 furthermore, the league of rights joined the chorus of concern over the role and influence of ettridge and david oldfield, hanson’s political adviser, who with hanson became known as ‘the troika’, in creating an undemocratic party structure. the lack of formal ties did not, however, mean that the league of rights had no influence in one nation.
attributes.response: YES, David Oldfield is mentioned as Pauline Hanson's political adviser.

Text: apart from browne, founding members included quentin spedding, an employee of ezra norton's daily mirror, for whom browne also worked, john hawkins, a sydney solicitor, and ken gates, a waterside worker.56 all these men had been involved in the battle veterans' association that waged a campaign within the returned soldiers, sailors and airmen imperial league of australia (rsl) to ban communists. the origins of this association lay in 1946 when browne was involved in a stunt throwing a red flag at the then president of the rsl.57 later hawkins, in particular, became prominent in the australian party.58 upon his release from goulburn gaol in september 1955, browne contributed a series of articles about his experiences as an inmate to the daily mirror.59 these were browne at his best, justifiably railing against his incarceration and damning his enemies, in particular prime minister menzies and the leader of the opposition, dr evatt.
attributes.response: [YES, 'ken gates is listed as one of the founding members along with quentin spedding']

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nation’s title, which was akin to confederate action party’s slogans ‘we are one nation’ and ‘one flag one nation’.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, ‘all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing’, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nation’s expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisis—the cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading ‘new world order’—much of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tony’s wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archer’s criticism of hanson that led to archer’s expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australia’s leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: YES, 'Tony Pitt was a former member of the confederate action party and later became a leading figure in the far-right Wake Up Australia!'

Text: evonne moore, an unley city councillor (adelaide) and australians against further immigration candidate, has analysed the growth of an anti-immigration impulse in the australian environmentalist movement.81 she explained the development of a population debate within the australian conservation foundation centred around dr. geoff mosley.82 it occasioned a dilemma, whereby some environmentalists believed they would be accused of racism in pushing for immigration-restriction, and while employing rhetoric about sustainability, they abandoned the field.83 the gap was filled by australians for an ecologically sustainable population, writers for an ecologically sustainable population (supported by poets judith wright and mark oconnor) - and australians against immigration. the former groups specifically repudiated any idea of racial preference.
attributes.response: YES, evonne moore is a member of australians against immigration.

Text: ‘if australians looked behind the [one nation] banner and saw some of these old faces coming out again’, federal treasurer peter costello said, referring to the league of rights, ‘they would be horrified to know who is behind it and who has a very significant influence in it’.2 costello’s comment was triggered by one nation’s economic policy of 2 per cent low-interest loans, and an off-the-cuff call by one nation director david ettridge for printing more money, both of which were policies long advocated by the league of rights. by its own admission the league of rights identified with hanson; its octogenarian leader eric butler stated that the league of rights agreed with her ‘views and policies’.3 describing the ‘hanson miracle’ as ‘a catalyst in a type of political turning-point in australian politics’, he argued: ‘the value of pauline hanson’s service to australian politics is incalculable, and will only be seen in its true perspective in time to come.’4 it followed that the league of rights encouraged its activists to support her,5 while its outlets sold copies of the truth, the racist tract published by hanson’s support movement described below.
attributes.response: YES, David Ettridge is mentioned as the director of Pauline Hanson's One Nation party.

Text: however, there was still room for co-operation: national action stated that, with the right, it goes ‘marching separately, striking together’, while maintaining its independence.81 unlike other racist groups, such as australians against further immigration, which saw its future as dependent on and integrated with one nation, national action members believe the future is theirs for the taking. in the article ‘one nation party/ australia first party crises: can nationalists fill the political gap?’, they argue that national action can fill in where one nation and australia first have left off, that is, by organizing ‘street level propaganda campaigns’, secondary school activities, university actions and street demonstrations, and by ‘build[ing] a party of effective cadres who can give leadership to australians in direct struggle’.82 there is some recent evidence, albeit from far-right sources, that one nation members in the riverina region of new south wales have left the party and are seeking to establish a branch of national action.
attributes.ent1_notes: saw themselves as filling a gap left by one nationa and australians against further immigration
attributes.response: YES, 'Australians against Further Immigration saw its future as dependent on and integrated with One Nation.'

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nation’s title, which was akin to confederate action party’s slogans ‘we are one nation’ and ‘one flag one nation’.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, ‘all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing’, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nation’s expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisis—the cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading ‘new world order’—much of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tony’s wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archer’s criticism of hanson that led to archer’s expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australia’s leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: YES, husband and wife

Text: political support for the australian far-right’s anti-islamism extends beyond southeast asia. for instance, in october 2015, dutch politician and leader of the party for freedom in the house of representatives, geert wilders, travelled to perth to promote the new anti-islamic “australian liberty alliance.”67 in december 2017, a crowd of australian far-right individuals, adorned with pro-trump memorabilia, welcomed the anti-islamic far-right provocateur milo yiannopoulos during a seminar tour.68 in july 2018, alt-right magnates lauran southern and stefan molyneux disseminated anti-“other” sentiment during their speaking tour.69 in his november 2018 speaking tour alongside ann coulter, milo seeks to return to australia for a second round of public dialogues.70 following milo’s first tour, a slew of far-right violence erupted against rival anti-fascist and counter-protesters.71 these international far-right coalitions legitimatised views of “us” against muslims, as a global and shared problem.

Text: shout, “i’m proud to be a militiaman or reservist in the patriotic sense. i am proud to carry a firearm in defence of my australia”.’42 indeed, the party’s queensland mps invested considerable time and resources in a bill to liberalize gun ownership, which declared that ‘disarming law abiding australians is not in the national interest’.43 32 a gun culture permeated the party; south australian president len spencer wore a concealed gun at one nation meetings.44 it was this culture that attracted the militias, with australians united survival individual freedom scouts queensland director ron heppes openly admitting that most of his people were either one nation members or supporters.45 hanson welcomed militia leaders, many of whom were associated with the league of rights, at the highest levels of the party.

Text: greason (1997) described them as developing since the second world war in three broad waves: the explicitly nazi nationalist socialist party of australia (nspa) in the 1960s; the less symbolically laden (that is, no swastikas) national front of australia and the australian national alliance during the 1970s and early 1980s; and national action (na) from the early 1980s onwards. a return to explicit nazi ideology and paraphernalia was evident in the national action breakaway group, the australian nationalist movement (australian nationalist movement), formed in 1984 because its leader believed that national action was insufficiently explicit in its anti-semitism and neo-naziism.
attributes.response: [YES, 'The explicitly nazi National Socialist Party of Australia (NSPA) in the 1960s']

Text: the australians’ south australian contact, algie walker, claimed to be a member of one nation and, according to west australian organizer alan rossiter, he and all his members joined one nation to whom they donated their funds.26 reflecting the extent to which confederate action party was the foundation on which one nation stood, the one nation support movement was established and led by former confederate action party candidate bruce whiteside. it was through whiteside, who expressed his adulation for hanson by telling her ‘i can honestly say i love you’,27 that a grassroots movement was established through which tens of thousands of australians were mobilized to rally and vote for hanson.

Text: the australians’ south australian contact, algie walker, claimed to be a member of one nation and, according to west australian organizer alan rossiter, he and all his members joined one nation to whom they donated their funds.26 reflecting the extent to which confederate action party was the foundation on which one nation stood, the one nation support movement was established and led by former confederate action party candidate bruce whiteside. it was through whiteside, who expressed his adulation for hanson by telling her ‘i can honestly say i love you’,27 that a grassroots movement was established through which tens of thousands of australians were mobilized to rally and vote for hanson.

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nation’s title, which was akin to confederate action party’s slogans ‘we are one nation’ and ‘one flag one nation’.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, ‘all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing’, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nation’s expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisis—the cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading ‘new world order’—much of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tony’s wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archer’s criticism of hanson that led to archer’s expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australia’s leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: [YES, 'Tony Pitt gave secret recordings to David Ettridge']

Text: members of the organization have highlighted and drawn from these events to promote the united patriots fronts anti-islam, anti-immigration platform, and to connect with a panoply of international reactionary movements. for example, in addition to the 2015 charlie hebdo example previously discussed, cottrell, sewell, and shermon posted scaremongering articles and commentary on facebook and twitter about the sydney siege by gunman man haron monis on 15 december 2014,119 the 2 october 2015 shooting of victoria police worker curtis cheng, and the 6 june 2017 brighton siege in victoria, in which yacqub khayre shot a hotel clerk, kai hao, and took three women hostage.120 with respect to international events, a characteristic united patriots front response to is-related events was cottrells twitter post following the 4 june 2017 london bridge borough market: sometimes the most simplistic solution is the best and only one.

Text: neo-nazism chief among evidence of the united patriots fronts early collective habitus of neo-nazism are its interpersonal associations. as the antifascist activist, andy fleming, aka slackbastard, has revealed, erikson was variously photographed meeting infamous canadian holocaust denier paul fromm, at a musical performance by the neo-nazi hammerskins organization in melbourne in october 2011, at the geert wilders meeting at the la mirage receptions in somerton, victoria in february 2013 during which several neo-nazi figures were present, and at an anti-muslim rally with well-known australian white supremacists outside the victoria state library in september 2012.90 indicating the prevalence of such sentiments within the organization, a post on cottrells instagram page displays founders and leaders of the group, sewell and cottrell, in the company of three other men, celebrating adolf hitlers birthday at a german restaurant in melbourne, while making a pinched thumb and forefinger sign,91 a gesture that cottrell is making in his current twitter photo, and which the group publicly acknowledged has become recently associated with white supremacy.

Text: neo-nazism chief among evidence of the united patriots fronts early collective habitus of neo-nazism are its interpersonal associations. as the antifascist activist, andy fleming, aka slackbastard, has revealed, erikson was variously photographed meeting infamous canadian holocaust denier paul fromm, at a musical performance by the neo-nazi hammerskins organization in melbourne in october 2011, at the geert wilders meeting at the la mirage receptions in somerton, victoria in february 2013 during which several neo-nazi figures were present, and at an anti-muslim rally with well-known australian white supremacists outside the victoria state library in september 2012.90 indicating the prevalence of such sentiments within the organization, a post on cottrells instagram page displays founders and leaders of the group, sewell and cottrell, in the company of three other men, celebrating adolf hitlers birthday at a german restaurant in melbourne, while making a pinched thumb and forefinger sign,91 a gesture that cottrell is making in his current twitter photo, and which the group publicly acknowledged has become recently associated with white supremacy.

Text: campbells ultimate sin was to address a november australians against further immigration conference, which brought his expulsion from the australian labor party.169in early 1996, campbell commenced approaches to the gun lobby around victorian sporting shooters association president, ted drane; through his friends of graeme campbell he organized meetings to prepare for an australia first party.170 his labor nationalism and protectionism, and the enviro-cultural anti-immigration stand of his australians against further immigration allies, also attracted queensland recruits from the direct democracy and local branch faction of the confederate action party.171 the pace of these developments elicited counter-reactions from australia-israel review, which lobbied to alienate the shooters and sow disputation.172whereas connor and campbell were pale versions of langite nationalism, they could be seen in that tradition. the essential fluidity of their labor politics easily produced positions akin to australians against further immigration and confederate action party.

Text: before reclaim australia’s nation-wide demonstrations on april 4, 2015, a code of conduct was distributed on and offline with consideration to the participants of the demonstrations. with 16 rallies occurring over two days in various cities and regional centres across australia and featuring a speech from one nation party leader pauline hanson, the rallies orientated their vehement rejections of the most contentious aspects of islam like sharia, islamist violent extremism, and the burkha.28 reclaim australia prepared participants with such cautions: nothing should be carried that could remotely be described as a weapon.
attributes.response: YES, Pauline Hanson, the leader of One Nation Party, gave a speech at one of the rallies organized by reclaim australia.

Text: ‘if australians looked behind the [one nation] banner and saw some of these old faces coming out again’, federal treasurer peter costello said, referring to the league of rights, ‘they would be horrified to know who is behind it and who has a very significant influence in it’.2 costello’s comment was triggered by one nation’s economic policy of 2 per cent low-interest loans, and an off-the-cuff call by one nation director david ettridge for printing more money, both of which were policies long advocated by the league of rights. by its own admission the league of rights identified with hanson; its octogenarian leader eric butler stated that the league of rights agreed with her ‘views and policies’.3 describing the ‘hanson miracle’ as ‘a catalyst in a type of political turning-point in australian politics’, he argued: ‘the value of pauline hanson’s service to australian politics is incalculable, and will only be seen in its true perspective in time to come.’4 it followed that the league of rights encouraged its activists to support her,5 while its outlets sold copies of the truth, the racist tract published by hanson’s support movement described below.
attributes.response: [YES, 'One Nation's economic policy and call for printing more money were influenced by the League of Rights, which identified with Hanson']

Text: ‘if australians looked behind the [one nation] banner and saw some of these old faces coming out again’, federal treasurer peter costello said, referring to the league of rights, ‘they would be horrified to know who is behind it and who has a very significant influence in it’.2 costello’s comment was triggered by one nation’s economic policy of 2 per cent low-interest loans, and an off-the-cuff call by one nation director david ettridge for printing more money, both of which were policies long advocated by the league of rights. by its own admission the league of rights identified with hanson; its octogenarian leader eric butler stated that the league of rights agreed with her ‘views and policies’.3 describing the ‘hanson miracle’ as ‘a catalyst in a type of political turning-point in australian politics’, he argued: ‘the value of pauline hanson’s service to australian politics is incalculable, and will only be seen in its true perspective in time to come.’4 it followed that the league of rights encouraged its activists to support her,5 while its outlets sold copies of the truth, the racist tract published by hanson’s support movement described below.

Text: just as one nation did not emerge in isolation, but rather on the foundations of the confederate action party, it is likely to give rise to other extremist organizations. to date this includes the city country alliance and the australian one nation party established by disenchanted members,94 as was the australian united peoples movement, whose co-founders include john abbott, a former one nation national vice-president.95 none of these are likely to pose a serious electoral threat, but they provide another front for the far right with which both one nation and the wider community will have to contend.

Text: the australians’ south australian contact, algie walker, claimed to be a member of one nation and, according to west australian organizer alan rossiter, he and all his members joined one nation to whom they donated their funds.26 reflecting the extent to which confederate action party was the foundation on which one nation stood, the one nation support movement was established and led by former confederate action party candidate bruce whiteside. it was through whiteside, who expressed his adulation for hanson by telling her ‘i can honestly say i love you’,27 that a grassroots movement was established through which tens of thousands of australians were mobilized to rally and vote for hanson.

Text: the truth’s claim that australia was legally acquired by britain, its denial of genocide and assertion that aborigines were not indigenous to australia, but immigrants like everyone else, provided the basis upon which one nation could assert its opposition to land rights. the truth’s contributors included south australian academic joseph wayne smith, who was chairman of the league of rights off-shoot australian patriots,33 and australians against further immigration’s denis mccormack.34 overall, although there was clear confederate action party influence in one nation, it is wrong to conclude from these contacts that confederate action party controlled one nation.
attributes.response: [YES, 'Joseph Wayne Smith, as chairman of the league of rights off-shoot Australian Patriots, was a contributor to The Truth newspaper.']

Text: besides the league of rights, the australian nationalist movement, and national action, the report lists: the adelaide institute, organized by holocaust revisionist fredrick toben (toben was ordered by the federal court to remove holocaust denial material from his website in september 2002 under commonwealth racial vilification law—the law report, 24 september 2002); the covenant vision ministry in sydney’s outer western suburbs; the christian identity ministries of far north queensland; and the citizens electoral council (cec), based in melbourne, which follow lyndon larouche. newly formed neo-nazi groups include white australian revolutionaries, australian national socialist movement, c18, the australian revolutionary movement, and daughters of the celts.

Text: the true nature of the league of rights – one nation relationship was articulated by butler’s successor, david thompson, who told the league of rights supporters they should ‘resent’ claims that one nation is a the league of rights front, which he dismissed as an attempt to undermine support for hanson.6 in the organization’s most explicit statement on one nation he wrote: ‘while we have made every effort to distribute pauline hanson’s addresses as widely as possible, and offered every encouragement to others to support her in the raising of the issues with which she has become associated, the league of rights has had no contact with pauline hanson whatever’ (italic and underlined in original).7 furthermore, the league of rights joined the chorus of concern over the role and influence of ettridge and david oldfield, hanson’s political adviser, who with hanson became known as ‘the troika’, in creating an undemocratic party structure. the lack of formal ties did not, however, mean that the league of rights had no influence in one nation.
attributes.response: [YES, 'The league of rights joined the chorus of concern over the role and influence of ettridge and david oldfield, hanson’s political adviser, who with hanson became known as ‘the troika’, in creating an undemocratic party structure.']

Text: greason (1997) described them as developing since the second world war in three broad waves: the explicitly nazi nationalist socialist party of australia (nspa) in the 1960s; the less symbolically laden (that is, no swastikas) national front of australia and the australian national alliance during the 1970s and early 1980s; and national action (na) from the early 1980s onwards. a return to explicit nazi ideology and paraphernalia was evident in the national action breakaway group, the australian nationalist movement (australian nationalist movement), formed in 1984 because its leader believed that national action was insufficiently explicit in its anti-semitism and neo-naziism.
attributes.response: [YES, 'The explicitly nazi National Socialist Party of Australia (NSPA) in the 1960s']

Text: greason (1997) described them as developing since the second world war in three broad waves: the explicitly nazi nationalist socialist party of australia (nspa) in the 1960s; the less symbolically laden (that is, no swastikas) national front of australia and the australian national alliance during the 1970s and early 1980s; and national action (na) from the early 1980s onwards. a return to explicit nazi ideology and paraphernalia was evident in the national action breakaway group, the australian nationalist movement (australian nationalist movement), formed in 1984 because its leader believed that national action was insufficiently explicit in its anti-semitism and neo-naziism.

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nation’s title, which was akin to confederate action party’s slogans ‘we are one nation’ and ‘one flag one nation’.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, ‘all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing’, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nation’s expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisis—the cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading ‘new world order’—much of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tony’s wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archer’s criticism of hanson that led to archer’s expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australia’s leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: [YES, 'peter archer, formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy']
attributes.ent2_notes: on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy

Text: however, there was still room for co-operation: national action stated that, with the right, it goes ‘marching separately, striking together’, while maintaining its independence.81 unlike other racist groups, such as australians against further immigration, which saw its future as dependent on and integrated with one nation, national action members believe the future is theirs for the taking. in the article ‘one nation party/ australia first party crises: can nationalists fill the political gap?’, they argue that national action can fill in where one nation and australia first have left off, that is, by organizing ‘street level propaganda campaigns’, secondary school activities, university actions and street demonstrations, and by ‘build[ing] a party of effective cadres who can give leadership to australians in direct struggle’.82 there is some recent evidence, albeit from far-right sources, that one nation members in the riverina region of new south wales have left the party and are seeking to establish a branch of national action.
attributes.ent1_notes: saw themselves as dependent on one nation
attributes.response: YES, 'Australians against Further Immigration saw its future as dependent on and integrated with One Nation.'

Text: however, there was still room for co-operation: national action stated that, with the right, it goes ‘marching separately, striking together’, while maintaining its independence.81 unlike other racist groups, such as australians against further immigration, which saw its future as dependent on and integrated with one nation, national action members believe the future is theirs for the taking. in the article ‘one nation party/ australia first party crises: can nationalists fill the political gap?’, they argue that national action can fill in where one nation and australia first have left off, that is, by organizing ‘street level propaganda campaigns’, secondary school activities, university actions and street demonstrations, and by ‘build[ing] a party of effective cadres who can give leadership to australians in direct struggle’.82 there is some recent evidence, albeit from far-right sources, that one nation members in the riverina region of new south wales have left the party and are seeking to establish a branch of national action.

Text: the true nature of the league of rights – one nation relationship was articulated by butler’s successor, david thompson, who told the league of rights supporters they should ‘resent’ claims that one nation is a the league of rights front, which he dismissed as an attempt to undermine support for hanson.6 in the organization’s most explicit statement on one nation he wrote: ‘while we have made every effort to distribute pauline hanson’s addresses as widely as possible, and offered every encouragement to others to support her in the raising of the issues with which she has become associated, the league of rights has had no contact with pauline hanson whatever’ (italic and underlined in original).7 furthermore, the league of rights joined the chorus of concern over the role and influence of ettridge and david oldfield, hanson’s political adviser, who with hanson became known as ‘the troika’, in creating an undemocratic party structure. the lack of formal ties did not, however, mean that the league of rights had no influence in one nation.

Text: apart from browne, founding members included quentin spedding, an employee of ezra norton's daily mirror, for whom browne also worked, john hawkins, a sydney solicitor, and ken gates, a waterside worker.56 all these men had been involved in the battle veterans' association that waged a campaign within the returned soldiers, sailors and airmen imperial league of australia (rsl) to ban communists. the origins of this association lay in 1946 when browne was involved in a stunt throwing a red flag at the then president of the rsl.57 later hawkins, in particular, became prominent in the australian party.58 upon his release from goulburn gaol in september 1955, browne contributed a series of articles about his experiences as an inmate to the daily mirror.59 these were browne at his best, justifiably railing against his incarceration and damning his enemies, in particular prime minister menzies and the leader of the opposition, dr evatt.

Text: apart from browne, founding members included quentin spedding, an employee of ezra norton's daily mirror, for whom browne also worked, john hawkins, a sydney solicitor, and ken gates, a waterside worker.56 all these men had been involved in the battle veterans' association that waged a campaign within the returned soldiers, sailors and airmen imperial league of australia (rsl) to ban communists. the origins of this association lay in 1946 when browne was involved in a stunt throwing a red flag at the then president of the rsl.57 later hawkins, in particular, became prominent in the australian party.58 upon his release from goulburn gaol in september 1955, browne contributed a series of articles about his experiences as an inmate to the daily mirror.59 these were browne at his best, justifiably railing against his incarceration and damning his enemies, in particular prime minister menzies and the leader of the opposition, dr evatt.

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nation’s title, which was akin to confederate action party’s slogans ‘we are one nation’ and ‘one flag one nation’.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, ‘all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing’, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nation’s expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisis—the cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading ‘new world order’—much of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tony’s wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archer’s criticism of hanson that led to archer’s expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australia’s leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: YES, Paul Hilderbrand felt disposed to join One Nation as an ordinary member.
attributes.query2:
I am conducting a project mapping the Australian far-right political landscape as a social network.paul hilderbrand and pauline hanson's one nation party are either far-right groups or individuals.I need you to tell me if there is an EXPLICIT connection between paul hilderbrand and pauline hanson's one nation party.This means there must be a direct connection, such as two people directly knowing each other or a person being a member of a group.If there is an explicit connection, return YES and a one sentence summary of the connection, no longer than 12 words.Use this format: [YES, 'One sentence summary of connection']If there is not an EXPLICIT CONNECTION and paul hilderbrand and pauline hanson's one nation party co-occur in the text arbitrarily(i.e. they are listed next to each other in the text) then simply return NO (just print NO, nothing else).

DO NOT RELY ON YOUR OWN KNOWLEDGE TO ANSWER THE QUESTION - YOU MUST DRAW ONLY ON THE TEXT LISTED BELOW.

THE CONNECTION MUST BE EXPLICITLY MENTIONED IN THE TEXT BELOW.

ONLY CONSIDER THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN paul hilderbrand and pauline hanson's one nation party, DO NOT CONSIDER THEIR RELATIONSHIP WITH ANY OTHER ENTITY LISTED IN THE TEXT.

FOCUS ONLY ON paul hilderbrand and pauline hanson's one nation party AND ANSWER ONLY ABOUT paul hilderbrand and pauline hanson's one nation party. YOU ARE PROHIBITED FROM CONSIDERING ANY OTHER ENTITY OTHER THAN paul hilderbrand and pauline hanson's one nation party.

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nation’s title, which was akin to confederate action party’s slogans ‘we are one nation’ and ‘one flag one nation’.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, ‘all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing’, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nation’s expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisis—the cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading ‘new world order’—much of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tony’s wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archer’s criticism of hanson that led to archer’s expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australia’s leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
